instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D9701: What is D9701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.LCD_BKLT_EN: What is LCD_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “LCD_BKLT” which stands for “LCD screen backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR: What is PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR? PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR is PPBUS_G3H after it has passed through a backlight fuse and a transistor that allows power through when BKLT_PLT_RST_L and LCD_BKLT_EN are present. .
definitions.LVDS_IG_BKL_ON: What is LVDS_IG_BKL_ON? LVDS_IG_BKL_ON is equivalent to LCD_BKLT_EN. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT is the voltage rail for the backlight of the LCD screen. .
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
i have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook air logic board. liquid damaged... no backlight. did ultrasonic cleaning and measured fuse. fuse is ok. damage was main on LED driver. i was wondering what would be the diagnostic steps to know where the issue might be .

thanks in advance

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: It is just no backlight?? do you see any image on display?? what voltage do you have on <DIODE>D9701</DIODE>??

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: 7.74v. i put flashlight on apple logo on back and see harddrives when i press option

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
I just made this a sticky. 

[url]https://www.rossmanngroup.com/boards/forum/board-repair-troubleshooting/1145-macbook-air-no-backlight-troubleshooting-guide[/url]

If you can post your <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> voltage, <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> voltage, and tell me if ball a5 for feedback has continuity to backlight output, we can go from there.

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: thanks ill look in it

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> measured on <RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR> 2.7v

<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> - 3v

from a5 probe to <CAPACITOR>C9796</CAPACITOR> there is continuity

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: Do you have <SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR</SIGNAL>? If no Check <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL>......

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
3.3 <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_PWR</SIGNAL>
8.<SIGNAL>36LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
3.3v- <SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: but you have 7.4V on <DIODE>D9701</DIODE>??

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: yes <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> = 7.74v

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: ok missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> = <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> this signal cames from PCH, measure on diode mode red probe to ground pin 5 from <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR>, this could be a bad PCH....

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: diode mode red probe to ground pin 5 from <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> = 0.5to 1v in diode mode

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: diode mode red probe to ground black probe to pin 5 from <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> should give you a value about 0.400 or something like that..... are you sure it is just 1 ??

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: 0.39 something to 0.5. i was putting the probes the other way. yes 0.39

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R9741</RESISTOR> is showing 5 ohms. i was wondering if that has relation to the no backlight or does that relate to something else

also i saw some corrosion on <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR>... very minor but now pin 5 is getting 3.3v 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR</SIGNAL>=8.36v now. dont know what happen but these voltages are coming through. but still no backlight

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: If there is 5 ohm over <RESISTOR>R9741</RESISTOR> then <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> is probably bad.

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
[QUOTE="aprendiz, post: 1153"]Do you have <SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR</SIGNAL>? If no Check <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL>......[/QUOTE]



Let's stop a second. If he has 7.74v on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>, that means <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> are doing their job. I am guessing 7.74v means his multimeter batteries are dying more than anything else. A bad LED driver is the most likely case here.

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight

Yes. It was the led driver. Thank you. And Louis, my battery was dead. Thank you very much 

Aprendiz. There was nothing wrong you did. I really appreciate your help. I learned a few things I didn't know before.
